Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Microwave Auto-Oscillators Driven by Pure Spin Currents

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to develop and study the characteristics of microwave magnetic auto-oscillators driven by pure spin currents.
The intellectual merit is a deeper understanding of phenomena induced in nanoscale magnetic systems by spin currents, which will be facilitated by the new, previously inaccessible structures and geometries of devices driven by spin currents, by the development of advanced magnetic characterization techniques - micro-focus Brillouin Light Spectroscopy and x-ray dichroism microscopy, and by the advances in theoretical understanding of nanoscale magnetic systems.
The broader impacts are enhanced competitiveness of US science/technology, training of specialists for the electronics industry, and general public education. Namely, a new class of microwave auto-oscillators developed in this program will help maintain US leadership in microwave electronics. Undergraduate and graduate students will be exposed to the modern methods of fabrication and characterization of spintronic nanostructures, and will interact with the leading scientists. Outreach activities including lectures and demonstrations on nanoscience and nanotechnology tailored for K-12 teachers and students will scientifically inform the general public. Student education will be enhanced through the incorporation of theoretical and experimental methods of nanotechnology and spintronics into the graduate and undergraduate curricula.
The main transformative aspect of the proposal will be the development of a qualitatively new type of active spin-based devices where spin currents will be used directly, without being accompanied by charge currents, opening the possibilities for using new types of materials and device geometries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:     

    The main aim of the rapidly developing field of nano-spintronics is to replace the charge of electron by the spin (or the inherent mechanical moment ) of  electron  as a main carrier of information in the modern signal processing systems.

    Recent breakthroughs in the studies of the influence of pure spin currents on magnetization dynamics in ferromagnets have created a possibility to develop a new class of microwave devices – magnetic auto-oscillators driven by pure spin currents, or spin-current auto-oscillators (SCAO).  

        In 2012 we demonstrated that, using a spin-Hall effect in a layered structure consisting of  a heavy metal with strong spin-orbital interaction (Platinum) and a magnetic metal ( Permalloy), it is possible to separate  charge and spin currents, and,  using an in-plane concentrator of the spin current, to excite microwave-frequency auto-oscillations  in  a Permalloy film.

   The main goals of the research program supported by the grant NSF EPMD 1305574 was to understand the nature of the dynamical modes excited by spin currents in magnetic metallic ferromagnetic nanostructures, to create novel experimental prototypes of SCAO, to develop the theory of operation of SCAO, and to optimize their characteristics for practical applications.

     We assembled a synergistic team of specialists in experimental spintronics from Emory University, leading theorists in magnetization dynamics from Oakland University, and enlisted assistance from leading experts in micro-focus Brillouin Light Spectroscopy (μ-BLS) at the Muenster University (Germany), thus utilizing the full spectrum of modern experimental and theoretical  research methods . 

Intellectual merit:

    This allowed us to achieve the following important outcomes:

We demonstrated that dynamical modes excited in a SCAO by a spin current are self-localized nonlinear spin wave packets (so–called  “spin wave “bullets”), and that a SCAO can be effectively synchronized to an external microwave signal (see Fig.1).   This result was published in : V. E. Demidov et al.,   Nature Communications 5, 3179  (2014).

We developed a novel type of SCAO that uses nonlocal spin injection as an efficient mechanism for creation of pure spin currents not tied to the electrical charge transfer.  We demonstrated that such non-local SCAOs (Fig.2) exhibit a small oscillation linewidth, are tunable over a wide frequency range by the static magnetic field, and can be described by a simple quasi-linear dynamical model that reproduces well their oscillation characteristics. This result was published in :  V. E. Demidov et al., , Scientific Reports 5, 8578 (2015).

Studying SCAOs based on magnetic nanowires, we demonstrated that tapering of the  nanowire , which serves as the STO active region, significantly decreases the spectral linewidth of the generated signal, (and, therefore, the phase noise) in the auto-oscillator (see Fig.3). The observed linewidth narrowing was explained in the framework of the Ginzburg-Landau auto-oscillator model. This result was published in :  L. Yang et al., Scientific Reports 5, 16942 (2015).

We proposed a mechanism for transformation of a spin current in a bi-anisotropic antiferromagnetic (AFM) insulator  (see Fig.4). It was demonstrated theoretically that a thin layer of a bi-anisotropic antiferromagnetic (AFM) insulator can effectively conduct spin current through the excitation of a pair of evanescent AFM spin wave modes. The spin current flowing through the AFM is not conserved due to the interaction between the excited AFM modes and the AFM lattice and, depending on the excitation conditions, can be either attenuated or enhanced. This result was published in  R.Khymyn et al, Phys. Rev. B 93, 224421 (2016). These  findings open a way for the development of a new research field – spintronics of AFM insulators, and for the creation of THz-frequency auto-oscillators based on the AFM insulators. 

 

 Broader impact:

     We firmly believe the theory of SCAO based on ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic materials developed in this research program will lead to the creation of a novel class of on-chip microwave-frequency and THz-frequency signal generators compatible with the existing planar semiconductor technology and having sufficiently low phase noise for practical applications.

      The students and postdoctoral fellows educated while participating in this research program will contribute to the development of a skilled workforce and informed public in the fields of nanoscience and nanotechnology, and will have a significant positive impact on our society in general, while helping to maintain the U.S. dominance in this critical area  of technological research and development.

     We also made a coordinated effort to reach a broader audience at the K–12 levels through participation in the job fairs at the Utica Community Schools with accessible presentations on the modern developments in nano-scale magneto-electronics. This program of school visits was aimed at attracting young students to future careers in science and technology.

   We are also sure that the qualifications of our students trained in the process of this research in the most advanced methods of the modern theory of magnetism and  experimental methods of nano-spintronics  will help them make  successful careers in science and technology.
